text:
Hey Spencer! I'm feeling something similar. I love networking IRL but my communities haven't bounced back yet, so I've been relying on the same channels. 

I've done a few quick 30min lunch chats w industry folks and it's been a good refresh. Let's set one up if you're interested.

text:
Hi everyone! I’m a senior in college recruiting for entry level marketing-related roles at agencies and tech companies and I want to ask about what makes a stand-out application.
• For context: I’ve worked at an agency as performance marketing intern for 5 months and have done multiple content marketing projects through clubs. I use a clean, easy-to-read resume that I designed myself for applications. Within the past month, I’ve applied to 20+ roles (some with cover letters but most without) and haven’t heard back for a majority of them.
• The question(s): How can I make my resume stand out for entry-level roles? Do recruiters want cover letters (in all honesty) — and if so, what makes a good cover letter? What part of the application determines whether an applicant is a good enough fit for an interview?
Any input and/or tips would be greatly appreciated! Thank you :slightly_smiling_face:
*Also, if you know anyone who’s hiring entry-level marketers (or if you’re hiring!) shoot me a PM! I’d love to chat.

elements.text: Hi everyone! I’m a senior in college recruiting for entry level marketing-related roles at agencies and tech companies and I want to ask about what makes a stand-out application.

For context: I’ve worked at an agency as performance marketing intern for 5 months and have done multiple content marketing projects through clubs. I use a clean, easy-to-read resume that I designed myself for applications. Within the past month, I’ve applied to 20+ roles (some with cover letters but most without) and haven’t heard back for a majority of them.

The question(s): How can I make my resume stand out for entry-level roles? Do recruiters want cover letters (in all honesty) — and if so, what makes a good cover letter? What part of the application determines whether an applicant is a good enough fit for an interview?
Any input and/or tips would be greatly appreciated! Thank you
*Also, if you know anyone who’s hiring entry-level marketers (or if you’re hiring!) shoot me a PM! I’d love to chat.

text:
I’m a hiring manager, not a recruiter, and I may be in the minority, but I love the cover letter. I just hired for two jr roles in Dec — each with 300+ applicants. I start by scanning the resumes and looking for relevant experience — for me, B2B is preferred. But if they don’t have that, do they have similar experience in B2C, internships or clubs.

If I’m interested or on the fence, then I will look at the cover letter. That’s where you can write in complete sentences, highlight relevant experience, and differentiate yourself. Tell me why you’re the right candidate and make me excited to meet with you. Be personable. In the cover letter, I also consider writing style and grammar — it’s an indication of how the applicant might write business emails or other written communication, which is super important.

If I’m on the fence, and there is no cover letter, I pass. If I’m interested and there is no cover letter, I will still tag for a phone screening (1st step). If I’m interested in the resume and the cover letter gets me more excited, you start ahead of every other applicant.

In terms of “what part of the application determines if you are a fit for the interview?” — I have key skills or experience that I’m looking for — outlined in the job description. I look at every resume for 10-30 seconds and that’s what I’m looking for.

It’s tough to get your first job out of college. Hang in there and keep at it. You might apply for tons of jobs and do some A/B testing on resumes and cover letter messaging to see if there’s something that works better than others. Then you’ll be a step ahead when you find a job you really want.

elements.text:
I’m a hiring manager, not a recruiter, and I may be in the minority, but I love the cover letter. I just hired for two jr roles in Dec — each with 300+ applicants. I start by scanning the resumes and looking for relevant experience — for me, B2B is preferred. But if they don’t have that, do they have similar experience in B2C, internships or clubs.

If I’m interested or on the fence, then I will look at the cover letter. That’s where you can write in complete sentences, highlight relevant experience, and differentiate yourself. Tell me why you’re the right candidate and make me excited to meet with you. Be personable. In the cover letter, I also consider writing style and grammar — it’s an indication of how the applicant might write business emails or other written communication, which is super important.

If I’m on the fence, and there is no cover letter, I pass. If I’m interested and there is no cover letter, I will still tag for a phone screening (1st step). If I’m interested in the resume and the cover letter gets me more excited, you start ahead of every other applicant.

In terms of “what part of the application determines if you are a fit for the interview?” — I have key skills or experience that I’m looking for — outlined in the job description. I look at every resume for 10-30 seconds and that’s what I’m looking for.

It’s tough to get your first job out of college. Hang in there and keep at it. You might apply for tons of jobs and do some A/B testing on resumes and cover letter messaging to see if there’s something that works better than others. Then you’ll be a step ahead when you find a job you really want.

text:
Cross-post from the team-mgmt channel:


Hi, everyone. I’m executive editor of <http://Future.com|Future.com>, part of venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz. Previously, I was VP of content at NerdWallet, which IPO’d last year.

A request for any folks who work in content or marketing:

I’m currently crowd-sourcing compensation info directly from individuals. If you share your info with me, I will share back all the entries I collect from individuals. That’s in the interest of knowing where you stand in the market and whether you can do better.

This is what entries will look like for example, once I anonymize them:

• Editor in chief at a business trade publication / website based in NYC. Manages 10. Hybrid remote. $180k base. 25% bonus. $35k RSUs (vesting over three years).
• VP of marketing at a series B startup based in the Bay Area. 100% remote. $250k base. 30% bonus. .75 equity in the company, vested over four years.
Note: I don’t collect the original info anonymously, because I use such info to make recommendations to startups and other companies on how to pay so they’re competitive in the market for talent. I need to be able to trust the info I collect to make such recommendations, and that’s not possible with info collected anonymously.

FWIW, when I was at NerdWallet, leading a content team of ~100, we would crowd-source like this — our content folks would share what offers they were seeing from other employers. That’s so I could make sure that we stayed competitive in compensation. Because our team was large and many of us were recruited for jobs, we could cross-check offers pretty easily.

In case useful, this is my LinkedIn profile: <http://www.linkedin.com/in/maggieleung1|http://www.linkedin.com/in/maggieleung1>

If you share your info with me and I share aggregated info with you, I will expect you to not publish it anywhere or otherwise distribute it. That’s because that would mean that there’d be much less incentive for more people to share such info with me, which would mean I couldn’t continue to help raise other boats.

My philosophy: I do not try to underpay or lowball people, because I want there to be strong compensation in my field. I want more and more good jobs to exist, so we can all have more choices.

Currently, I’m one of the best paid content people in the world. I couldn’t easily change jobs without taking a big cut at most companies. That’s not a big deal, because I can afford to retire if I want. I mention that in case it helps to know: I’m not your competition and I have no ulterior motive.

My agenda: I want content to be a force in business. I do not want content or marketing folks to be some kind of underclass. When salaries are opaque, that can happen much more easily.

If you want to share your info, please DM me.

The info needed:

• Your role or title
• Your base salary
• Any bonus
• Any equity
• Any signing bonus
• Where your employer is located
• Whether you can work 100% remotely permanently (because individuals can control cost of living if they can choose where to live)
Again, once I collect this info and know it’s reliable, I will then remove your name and anonymize your company name before sharing out the aggregated info among other content and marketing people who are participating. I will not share the info with nonparticipants.

attachments.text: The average content marketing salary is $93,725. Check out our salary report for more detailed data on job titles, experience and pay discrepancies.
